Here the fleeting moment of radiant splendor—how could mere words capture its workings? Thus it is said: “Vast and indistinct, none know its beginning.”

At first, when primal chaos remained undivided, the heart of heaven resided at the center, and the primordial yellow was indistinguishable—hence the words “first one loses the track.” Then, as the great flood parted and the root of heaven stirred, the myriad transformations returned of themselves—hence the words “later it becomes the sovereign lord,” echoing the *Kun* hexagram’s judgment: “First one strays, later one finds the master.” At this moment, the first yang revives, turning into the *Zhen* hexagram’s initial nine.

No level ground but has its slope—this is the Dao’s spontaneity. Change and flux grow ever more vigorous, waxing and waning in mutual dependence. The end of *Kun* is the beginning of *Fu*, like tracing an unbroken ring. Emperors and kings who ride and govern by this principle endure for a thousand generations. This passage speaks of movement and stillness begetting one another in endless cycles, serving as the chapter’s conclusion.

As the six yangs ascend and the fire is advanced, the six yins descend and the tally is withdrawn—extreme movement gives rise to stillness, extreme stillness to movement, all the natural workings of heaven’s Dao. Thus it is said: “No level ground but has its slope—this is the Dao’s spontaneity.” Yin and yang alternate, revealing the principles of exchange and transformation. When yang flourishes, yin must wane; when yin dissolves, yang must rest—hence the words “change and flux grow ever more vigorous, waxing and waning in mutual dependence.” Movement and stillness have no beginning, end and inception no limit. The close of *hui* is the start of *shuo*; the end of *hai* is the beginning of *zi*; the end of *Kun* is the start of *Fu*. One meets it yet sees no head, follows it yet sees no tail—thus it is said: “The end of *Kun* is the beginning of *Fu*, like tracing an unbroken ring.”

The subtlety of the firing times aligns above with the workings of creation and below with the human body. Within, it can govern the heart; without, it can govern the world. Emperors and kings who ride this Dao to govern endure for millennia; alchemists who attain this Dao to refine the heart preserve their dharma-body for a thousand kalpas—hence the words “emperors and kings who ride and govern endure for a thousand generations.” This being the final chapter of the middle section on governance, it concludes with imperial rule, corresponding to the preceding section’s final chapter on the *Mingtang* and the enactment of governance.

This chapter elaborates the great celestial cycle of firing times, complementing the previous chapter from beginning to end. Only after *Kan* and *Li* unite is the great elixir produced; once produced, it may be gathered; once gathered and placed in the crucible, it may be refined. The previous chapter spoke of the moment of gathering; this chapter speaks of the moment of refinement. For gathering, one must recognize the living *zi* hour’s operation, awaiting the juncture of *hui* and *shuo*, when the two luminaries merge their essences, the *geng* direction reveals the moon, and metal is born within water—amidst the indistinct and the profound, one then seeks the primordial pearl within the formless, moving true fire within non-action. When the moon is full and the elixir congeals, this is called the golden elixir.

For refinement, one must recognize the proper *zi* hour’s operation, awaiting the first stir of yang between *hai* and *zi*, when fire arises within water. Only then does one apply the method of closing *Ren* and opening *Du*, fanning with the wind of *Xun*, and pumping with the bellows. Seizing this moment of vigorous fire, one drives the river chariot, fully laden with golden liquid, reversing its flow upward from the *Taiyuan* pass to the celestial valley. At the moment of union, the hundred vessels return to the origin, the nine gates are thoroughly opened, golden essence penetrates the crown, and silver waves surge to the heavens—scenes too wondrous to describe in full. Once the union is complete and yang reaches its extreme, yin arises, and one must swiftly open the gates and withdraw the fire, gradually descending the tower of layers. At this juncture, one must guard against danger and peril, purifying thoughts and cleansing the heart, until the elixir is returned to the earthen crucible—this is called “when the union of *Qian* and *Kun* ceases, a single point falls into the yellow court.”

Once the elixir enters the crucible, one must employ the *mao-you* celestial cycle’s firing times to congeal it. When the sacred embryo is formed, further nurturing is required, along with the work of nursing. When the embryo is complete and qi is sufficient, the infant moves to the upper field, and the primordial spirit transforms and emerges, naturally uniting form and spirit, merging with the Dao in truth—this is called the ninefold transmutation of the golden liquid returning elixir.

Yet these two operations—one internal, one external—differ as heaven and earth. From the mouths of past sages, this transmission has been passed down without being committed to writing. Even Master Wei dared not fully disclose the celestial mechanism. He merely likened the waxing and waning of a single month to a single moment in the golden elixir’s workings, and the six yins and six yangs of a year to the nine transmutations of the returning elixir. The true firing times remain secretly embedded within. Those who study the Dao and meet a teacher must grasp the meaning and forget the image.

**Middle Section (Middle Volume on Nurturing Innate Nature, comprising four chapters—this being the central chapter)**

**Chapter Twenty: Returning Innate Nature and Life to the Origin**

To nurture innate nature is to extend life and await its fulfillment. Reflect deeply on what follows, and first consider what precedes. The body one receives is fundamentally empty and void. Primordial essence spreads like clouds, borne by qi at the outset. Yin and yang serve as measures, the dwelling of hun and po. The yang spirit is the sun’s hun; the yin spirit is the moon’s po. Hun and po serve as each other’s chambers. Innate nature presides within, establishing the inner boundary; emotions operate without, constructing the outer walls. When the walls are complete, the people are at peace. At this time, emotions harmonize with *Qian* and *Kun*.

*Qian* moves and extends, qi spreads and essence flows; *Kun* is still and receptive, serving as the Dao’s dwelling. The firm acts and retreats; the yielding transforms and nourishes. Nine returns, seven reversals, eight returns, six dwellings. The male is white, the female red—metal and fire restrain each other. Then water settles fire, the beginning of the five phases. Supreme goodness resembles water, clear and without blemish. The Dao’s form and image are the true one, difficult to depict. When it changes and spreads, each dwells in its own place.

Like a chicken’s egg, white and black correspond, spanning a single inch—this is the beginning. The four limbs, five viscera, sinews, and bones are all complete.

Even sages and worthies cannot fathom it, for it is said: “In the indistinct, yin and yang generate transformation; in the interwoven, heaven and earth suddenly revolve.”

chunks.original_text: 弥历十月，脱出其胞。 骨弱可卷，肉滑若饴。 此章言性命同出一源，立命正所以养性也。 将欲养性，延命却期。 审思后末，当虑其先。 人所禀躯，体本一无。 元精云布，因炁托初。 阴阳为度，魂魄所居。 此节言养性之功，当彻究性命根源也。 何谓性？ 一灵廓彻，圆同太虚，即资始之干元也； 何谓命？ 一炁絪缊，主持万化，即资生之坤元也； 此是先天性命，在父母未生以前，原是浑成一物，本无污染，不假修证； 一落有生以后，太极中分，性成命立两者，便当兼修； 然性本无去无来，命却有修有短，若接命不住，则一灵倏然长往矣。 修道之士要做养性功夫，必须从命宗下手。 故曰“将欲养性，延命却期”。 何谓却期？ 凡人之命各有定期，其来不能却，其去亦不能却，惟大修行人主张由我，不受造化陶冶； 命既立住，真性在其中矣。 人若不知本来真性末从何归，了性是末后大事，不知欲要反终，先当原始； 必须反复穷究，思我这点真性，未生以前从何而来？ 既生以后凭何而立？ 便知了命之不可缓矣。 故曰“审思后末，当虑其先”。 最后受胎之时，不过秉父精母血，包罗凝聚，结成幻躯，此乃有形之体，非真体也。 我之真体本同太虚，光光净净，本来原无一物； 故曰“人所禀躯，体本一无”。 及至十月胎圆，太虚中一点元精，如云行雨施，倏然依附，直入中宫神室，作我主人。 于是劈开祖窍， 地一声，天命之性遂分为一阴一阳矣。 盖后天造化之气，若非先天元精，则无主而不能灵； 先天元精若非后天造化之气，则无所依而不能立； 可见性命两者本不相离。 故曰“元精云布，因炁托初”。 后天之造化既分一阴一阳，阳之神为魂，魂主轻清，属东方木液； 阴之神为魄，魄主重滞，属西方金精； 两者分居坎离匡廓之内。 故曰“阴阳为度，魂魄所居”。 盖命之在人既属后天造化，便夹带情识在内，只因本来真性搀入无始以来业根，生灭与不生灭和合而成八识，识之幽微者为想，想之流浪者为情，情生智隔，想变体殊，颠倒真性，枉入轮回矣！ 所以学人欲了性者当先了命。 阳神日魂，阴神月魄。 魂之与魄，互为室宅。 性主处内，立置鄞鄂。 情主处外，筑为城郭。 城郭完全，人民乃安。 此节正言后天立命之功。 后天一魂一魄分属坎离，盖以太阳在卯，故离中日魂为阳之神； 太阴在酉，故坎中月魄为阴之神； 两者体虽各居，然离己日光正是月中玉兔，日魂返作阴神矣； 坎戊月精正是日中金乌，月魄返为阳神矣。 故曰“魂之与魄，互为室宅”。 后天两物虽分性命，其实祖性全寄于命； 盖一落阴阳，莫非命也。 且命元更转为情，盖阴阳之变合，莫非情也。 惟其性寄于命，故离中元精坎中元炁总谓之命； 惟其命转为情，故日中木魂月中金魄总谓之情； 只有祖窍中一点元神方是本来真性，元神为君，安一点于窍内，来去总不出门； 岂非“性主处内，立置鄞鄂”乎？ 精气为臣，严立堤防，前后左右，遏绝奸邪； 岂非“情主处外，筑为城郭”乎？ 堤防既固，主人优游于密室之中，不动不摇，不惊不怖； 故曰“城郭完全，人民乃安”。 始而处内之性已足制情，既而营外之情自来归性； 宾主互参，君臣道合，此为坎离交会，金丹初基，立命正所以养性也。
chunks.translated_text:
After ten months, it emerges from the womb.
Its bones are soft and pliable, its flesh smooth as malt sugar.

This passage speaks of *xing* (nature) and *ming* (life) sharing a single source—establishing *ming* is precisely how one nurtures *xing*.
To nurture *xing* is to extend *ming* and delay its appointed end.
Examine the latter and consider the former;
one must ponder what comes first.

The body one receives is fundamentally nothingness.
Primal essence spreads like clouds, relying on *qi* to take its first form.
Yin and yang serve as its measure, the dwelling of *hun* and *po*.

This section speaks of the work of nurturing *xing*—one must thoroughly investigate the root of *xing* and *ming*.

What is *xing*?
A single spirit, vast and penetrating, round as the great void—this is the *Qian* origin of all beginnings.
What is *ming*?
A single *qi*, entwined and nurturing, governing the ten thousand transformations—this is the *Kun* origin of all life.
This is the *xing* and *ming* of the primordial, existing before parents gave birth, originally a single undivided thing, inherently unstained, requiring no cultivation or verification.
Once born into existence, the Supreme Ultimate divides: *xing* takes form, *ming* is established—these two must then be cultivated together.
Yet *xing* fundamentally neither comes nor goes, while *ming* may be prolonged or shortened. If one fails to sustain *ming*, the single spirit will suddenly depart forever.
Those who cultivate the Dao and seek to nurture *xing* must begin with the root of *ming*.
Thus it is said: "To nurture *xing*, extend *ming* and delay its end."

What does "delay its end" mean?
Every person’s *ming* has a fixed term—its coming cannot be delayed, nor can its going.
Only those of great cultivation take control for themselves, unbound by the molding of creation.
Once *ming* is firmly established, true *xing* resides within it.

If one does not know where the original true *xing* ultimately returns, and *xing* is the great matter of the end, then to seek a return to the end, one must first trace its origin.
One must repeatedly inquire: from where did this speck of true *xing* come before birth?
By what does it stand after birth?
Then one will understand that the cultivation of *ming* cannot be delayed.
Thus it is said: "Examine the latter and consider the former."

At the moment of conception, one merely receives the father’s essence and mother’s blood, which gather and congeal into an illusory body—this is the formed body, not the true body.
The true body is originally one with the great void, luminous and pure, fundamentally empty of all things.
Thus it is said: "The body one receives is fundamentally nothingness."

When the ten-month gestation is complete, a speck of primal essence from the great void, like clouds moving and rain falling, suddenly attaches itself, entering directly into the central palace of the spirit chamber to become one’s master.
There, it splits open the ancestral aperture—with a single thunderous sound, the *xing* of Heaven’s mandate divides into one yin and one yang.

For the *qi* of later heaven’s creation, without the primal essence of earlier heaven, would have no master and could not become numinous.
For the primal essence of earlier heaven, without the *qi* of later heaven’s creation, would have no place to rely upon and could not stand.
Thus *xing* and *ming* are fundamentally inseparable.
Thus it is said: "Primal essence spreads like clouds, relying on *qi* to take its first form."

Once later heaven’s creation divides into one yin and one yang, the yang spirit becomes the *hun*, which governs the light and pure, belonging to the wood-fluid of the east.
The yin spirit becomes the *po*, which governs the heavy and stagnant, belonging to the metal-essence of the west.
The two dwell within the enclosure of *Kan* and *Li*.
Thus it is said: "Yin and yang serve as its measure, the dwelling of *hun* and *po*."

Since *ming* in humans belongs to later heaven’s creation, it carries with it emotions and consciousness.
Only because the original true *xing* intermingles with the karmic roots from beginningless time do arising-and-ceasing and non-arising-and-ceasing combine to form the eight consciousnesses.
The subtlest aspect of consciousness is thought; the wandering aspect of thought is emotion.
Emotion gives rise to the obstruction of wisdom; thought alters the body’s uniqueness.
Thus true *xing* is inverted, and one vainly enters the wheel of rebirth.

Therefore, those who seek to understand *xing* must first understand *ming*.

The yang spirit is the sun’s *hun*; the yin spirit is the moon’s *po*.
*Hun* and *po* serve as each other’s chambers.
*Xing* governs the interior, establishing boundaries and defenses.
Emotion governs the exterior, constructing walls and ramparts.
When walls and ramparts are complete, the people are at peace.

This section properly speaks of the work of establishing *ming* in later heaven.

In later heaven, the single *hun* and *po* are divided between *Kan* and *Li*.
Since the great yang resides in *mao*, the sun’s *hun* within *Li* is the yang spirit.
Since the great yin resides in *you*, the moon’s *po* within *Kan* is the yin spirit.
Though their bodies dwell separately, the sun’s light in *Li* is precisely the jade hare of the moon—thus the sun’s *hun* returns as a yin spirit.
The moon’s essence in *Kan* is precisely the golden crow of the sun—thus the moon’s *po* returns as a yang spirit.
Thus it is said: "*Hun* and *po* serve as each other’s chambers."

Though later heaven’s two things divide *xing* and *ming*, the original *xing* is entirely entrusted to *ming*.
For once yin and yang divide, all is *ming*.
Moreover, the root of *ming* further transforms into emotion, for the changes and unions of yin and yang are nothing but emotion.

Because *xing* is entrusted to *ming*, the primal essence within *Li* and the primal *qi* within *Kan* are both called *ming*.
Because *ming* transforms into emotion, the wood-*hun* of the sun and the metal-*po* of the moon are both called emotion.
Only the speck of original spirit within the ancestral aperture is the original true *xing*.
The original spirit is the sovereign, settled within the aperture, coming and going without ever leaving its gate.
Is this not "*Xing* governs the interior, establishing boundaries and defenses"?

Essence and *qi* are ministers, strictly establishing embankments, guarding front and back, left and right, cutting off all treachery and evil.
Is this not "Emotion governs the exterior, constructing walls and ramparts"?

When the embankments are firm, the master roams leisurely within the secret chamber, unmoving and unshaken, unstartled and unafraid.
Thus it is said: "When walls and ramparts are complete, the people are at peace."

First, the *xing* within is sufficient to restrain emotion; then, the emotion without naturally returns to *xing*.
Guest and host mutually unite; sovereign and minister follow the Dao.
This is the union of *Kan* and *Li*, the initial foundation of the golden elixir—establishing *ming* is precisely how one nurtures *xing*.

returns, six dwellings. The male is white, the female red—metal and fire restrain each other. Then water settles fire, the beginning of the five phases. Supreme goodness resembles water, clear and without blemish. The Dao’s form and image are the true one, difficult to depict. When it changes and spreads, each dwells in its own place.

Like a chicken’s egg, white and black correspond, spanning a single inch—this is the beginning. The four limbs, five viscera, sinews, and bones are all complete.

chunks.original_text: 爰斯之时，情合乾坤。 干动而直，炁布精流； 坤静而翕，为道舍庐。 刚施而退，柔化以滋。 此节言后天返为先天也。 后天坎离即是先天乾坤，只因乾坤一破，性转为情，从此情上用事，随声逐色，不能还元； 至于两物会合，城郭完而鄞鄂立，则情来归性，离中之阴复还于坤，坎中之阳复还于干矣。 故曰“爰斯之时，情合乾坤”。 干性至健，静则专而动则直，一点元神为精气之主宰，至刚至直而不可御。 故曰“干动而直，炁布精流”。 此言元神之立为鄞鄂，即所谓干元资始者也； 坤性至顺，动则辟而静则翕，干中真炁流布，坤乃顺而承之，一点元神絪缊化醇，韫养在中黄土釜。 故曰“坤静而翕，为道舍庐”。 此言元神之本来胞胎，即所谓坤元资生者也。 干父刚而主施，不过施得一点真气； 坤母柔而主化，须在中宫时时滋育，方得成胎。 故曰“刚施而退，柔化以滋”。 此言坎离会合，产出先天元神，即金丹妙用也。 九还七返，八归六居。 男白女赤，金火相拘。 则水定火，五行之初。 此节言四象五行混而为一炁也。 坎离既复为乾坤，则后天之四象五行无不返本归原矣。 何以言之？ 天一生水，地六成之，北方之精也。 地二生火，天七成之，南方之神也。 天三生木，地八成之，东方之魂也。 地四生金，天九成之，西方之魄也。 水火木金为四象，并中央戊己土为五行。 究竟所谓四象五行，只是坎离两物，坎卦从坤而出，北方之水属阴，本数得六，加以天一之阳，便合成七数； 离卦从干而出，南方之火属阳，本数得七，加以地二之阴，便合成九数； 今者北方之坎返而归干，南方之离还而归坤，岂非“九还七返”之象乎？ 北方之一归于南方之七，共得八数； 南方之二归于北方之六，亦得八数； 而独云居者，盖北方之一既归于南，止存水之成数，居其所而不迁，恰好六数矣。 岂非“八归六居” 之象乎？ 又须知四象原是两物，既然九还七返，自然八归六居矣。 故《悟真篇》单言还返，益见造化之妙； 二与七併配，成西方之金，色转为白； 一与六併配，成南方之火，色转为赤； 白属金，赤属火，取西方之金，炼以南方之火，故曰“男白女赤，金火相拘”。 天一之水从干宫而出，原是太阳真火； 地二之火从坤宫而出，原是太阴真水； 直到一返一还，方得以水归水，以火归火，复其原初本体，故曰“则水定火，五行之初”。 前云金火，此又何以云水火？ 盖后天造化之妙，只是一坎一离，而千变万化各异其名，以言乎坎离本位，则曰水火； 以言乎两弦之炁，则曰金水； 以言乎甲庚之用，则曰金木； 以言乎伏炼之功，则曰金火； 颠倒取用，不可穷诘，究只是水火二物，后天水火虽分二物，究只是先天一炁； 坎离既已复为乾坤，即此便是九还七返。 八归六居而化作先天一炁矣。 上善若水，清而无瑕。 道之形象，真一难图。 变而分布，各自独居。
chunks.translated_text:
At this moment, emotion harmonizes with Qian and Kun.
Qian moves and straightens, *qi* spreads and essence flows;
Kun is still and contracts, becoming the dwelling of the Dao.
The firm bestows and retreats; the yielding transforms and nourishes.
This passage speaks of the postnatal returning to the prenatal.

The postnatal Kan and Li are none other than the prenatal Qian and Kun. Yet once Qian and Kun are broken, *xing* turns into emotion, and from then on, emotion takes charge—chasing sounds and pursuing forms, unable to return to the origin. Only when the two substances unite, the city walls are complete, and the embankments are established, does emotion return to *xing*. The yin within Li reverts to Kun, and the yang within Kan reverts to Qian.
Thus it is said: "At this moment, emotion harmonizes with Qian and Kun."

The *xing* of Qian is supremely firm: when still, it is focused; when moving, it is direct. The primordial spirit governs essence and *qi* with absolute rigidity and straightness, unyielding.
Thus it is said: "Qian moves and straightens, *qi* spreads and essence flows."
This speaks of the primordial spirit establishing the embankments—what is called "Qian, the origin of beginnings."

The *xing* of Kun is supremely yielding: when moving, it opens; when still, it contracts. The true *qi* of Qian flows and spreads, and Kun compliantly receives it. The primordial spirit, intermingling and transforming, is nurtured within the Yellow Court’s crucible.
Thus it is said: "Kun is still and contracts, becoming the dwelling of the Dao."
This speaks of the primordial spirit’s original womb—what is called "Kun, the source of generation."

The father, Qian, is firm and governs bestowal, yet bestows only a single point of true *qi*;
The mother, Kun, is yielding and governs transformation, requiring constant nurturing in the Central Palace to form the embryo.
Thus it is said: "The firm bestows and retreats; the yielding transforms and nourishes."
This speaks of Kan and Li uniting to produce the prenatal primordial spirit—the wondrous workings of the golden elixir.

Nine returns, seven reverts;
Eight returns, six abides.
Male white, female red—
Metal and fire restrain each other.
Water settles fire, the beginning of the Five Phases.
This passage speaks of the Four Symbols and Five Phases merging into a single *qi*.

Once Kan and Li revert to Qian and Kun, the postnatal Four Symbols and Five Phases all return to their origin.
Why is this so?
Heaven One generates Water, Earth Six completes it—this is the essence of the North.
Earth Two generates Fire, Heaven Seven completes it—this is the spirit of the South.
Heaven Three generates Wood, Earth Eight completes it—this is the soul of the East.
Earth Four generates Metal, Heaven Nine completes it—this is the corporeal soul of the West.
Water, Fire, Wood, and Metal are the Four Symbols; together with the central Earth of Wu and Ji, they form the Five Phases.
Yet what are called the Four Symbols and Five Phases are merely the two substances, Kan and Li.
The Kan trigram emerges from Kun, and the Water of the North belongs to yin; its base number is six, but with the addition of Heaven One’s yang, it becomes seven.
The Li trigram emerges from Qian, and the Fire of the South belongs to yang; its base number is seven, but with the addition of Earth Two’s yin, it becomes nine.
Now, the Kan of the North returns to Qian, and the Li of the South reverts to Kun—is this not the image of "nine returns, seven reverts"?

The One of the North returns to the Seven of the South, totaling eight;
The Two of the South returns to the Six of the North, also totaling eight.
Yet it speaks of "abiding" because once the One of the North returns to the South, only the completion number of Water remains, abiding in its place without shifting—precisely six.
Is this not the image of "eight returns, six abides"?

Moreover, the Four Symbols originally derive from two substances. Since nine returns and seven reverts, eight naturally returns and six abides.
Thus the *Wuzhen Pian* speaks only of "returning and reverting," revealing the marvel of creation.
Two and Seven combine to form the Metal of the West, its color turning white;
One and Six combine to form the Fire of the South, its color turning red.
White belongs to Metal, red to Fire—taking the Metal of the West and refining it with the Fire of the South,
Thus it is said: "Male white, female red, Metal and fire restrain each other."

Heaven One’s Water emerges from the Qian Palace, originally the true fire of Great Yang;
Earth Two’s Fire emerges from the Kun Palace, originally the true water of Great Yin.
Only after one reverts and one returns do Water return to Water and Fire to Fire, restoring their original essence.
Thus it is said: "Water settles fire, the beginning of the Five Phases."

Earlier it spoke of Metal and Fire—why now of Water and Fire?
The marvel of postnatal creation lies solely in Kan and Li, yet its thousand transformations and myriad changes bear different names.
In terms of Kan and Li’s positions, they are called Water and Fire;
In terms of the *qi* of the two phases, they are called Metal and Water;
In terms of the functions of Jia and Geng, they are called Metal and Wood;
In terms of the work of refinement, they are called Metal and Fire.
Their applications are inverted and unfathomable, yet ultimately they are merely the two substances, Water and Fire.
Though postnatal Water and Fire are divided into two, they are fundamentally the single *qi* of the prenatal.
Once Kan and Li revert to Qian and Kun, this is precisely "nine returns, seven reverts, eight returns, six abides"—transforming into the single *qi* of the prenatal.

The highest good is like Water, pure and flawless.
The form and image of the Dao—true unity is hard to depict.
Though it changes and spreads, each abides in its own place.

Guest and host mutually unite; sovereign and minister follow the Dao.
This is the union of *Kan* and *Li*, the initial foundation of the golden elixir—establishing *ming* is precisely how one nurtures *xing*.

chunks.original_text: 此节言先天一炁为大丹之基也。 盖道本虚无，始生一炁，只此一炁，鸿蒙未分，便是先天真一之水，非后天有形之水也。 学道之士若能摄情归性，併两归一，才复得先天真水，水源至清至洁，此时身心打成一片，不染不杂，自然表里洞彻，有如万顷水壶，故曰“上善若水，清而无瑕”。 大道离相离名，本无形象，及其生出一炁，似乎可得而形容矣。 然此真一之炁，杳冥恍惚，形于无形，象于无象，非一切意识可以卜度揣摩而得。 故曰“道之形象，真一难图”。 真一之水便是中宫一点鄞鄂，所谓太一含真炁也。 合之为一炁，分之则为两物，又分之则为四象五行，交会之时，五行变化全在中央，既而木仍在东，金仍在西，火仍在南，水仍在北，各居其所矣。 故曰“变而分布，各自独居”。 此段言真一之水实为丹基。 《入药镜》所云“水乡铅，只一味”是也。 学者若知攒五合四，会两归一之旨，鄞鄂成而圣胎结矣。 类如鸡子，白黑相符，纵横一寸，以为始初。 四肢五脏，筋骨乃俱。 弥历十月，脱出其胞。 骨弱可卷，肉滑若饴。 此节特显法身之形象也。 圣胎初凝，一点元神潜藏神室，混混沌沌，元黄未剖，黑白未分，有如鸡子之状，故曰“类如鸡子，白黑相符”。 神室中间方圆恰好径吋，法身隐于其中优游充长，与赤子原初在母腹中一般造化，故曰“纵横一寸，以为始初”。 温养真胎，必须从微至着，始而成象，继而成形，四肢五脏併筋络骨节之类，件件完备，具体而微，故曰“四肢五脏，筋骨乃俱”。 须知四象五行包络法身，便如四肢五脏，法身渐渐坚凝，便如筋骨，非真有形象也。 温养既足，至于十月胎完，赤子从坤炉中跃然而出，上升干鼎，从此重安炉鼎，再造乾坤，别有一番造化； 我之法身才得通天彻地，混合太虚，故曰“弥历十月，脱出其胞”。 而有骨弱可卷，肉滑如饴之象矣。 此段言法身形象与母胎中生身受炁之初同一造化，但顺则生人，逆则成丹，有圣与凡之别耳。 此章是养性第一关键，与上篇两窍互用章相应。 二炁感化章第二十一 阳燧以取火，非日不生光。 方诸非星月，安能得水浆？ 二炁玄且远，感化尚相通，何况近存身？ 切在于心胸。 阴阳配日月，水火为效征。 此章言水火两弦之炁以同类相感也。 上章言魂之与魄互为室宅，即水火两物也。 金丹之道以日月为体，以水火为用； 体则互藏，用则交入； 日月非水火，体无所施； 水火非日月，用无所出，近取诸身，远取诸物，莫不皆然。 阳燧是火珠，形如铜镜，其体中实，象坎中一阳，此物秉太阳火精，故世人用以取火，然必向日中取之，才能得火，只因这点真阳，原是日魂之光，日为光之所聚，阳燧为光之所招，以火取火，安得不灵？ 故曰“阳燧以取火，非日不生光”。 方诸是蚌珠，其体中虚，象离中一阴，此物秉太阴水精，故世人用以取水，然必向月下取之，才能得水，只因这点真阴，原是月魄之精，月为精之所藏，方诸为精之所摄，以水取水，安得不应？ 故曰“方诸非星月，安能得水浆”。 此即坎离互用之旨也。 天上之日月与世间之水火，相去不知几万里，可谓元且远矣，然而隔阂潜通，如磁吸铁，正以同类易亲，故二炁自为感化而相通也。

This passage speaks of the primordial singular *qi* as the foundation of the Great Elixir. The Dao is fundamentally formless and void, yet from this void arises the singular *qi*. This singular *qi*, undifferentiated in the primordial chaos, is the true unity of prenatal Water—not the postnatal Water of tangible form. If a cultivator of the Dao can gather emotions into nature and merge dualities into oneness, they may recover this prenatal true Water. Its source is utterly pure and flawless; at this moment, body and mind fuse into one, unstained and unadulterated, naturally transparent within and without, like a vast expanse of water in a vessel—hence the saying, *"The highest good is like Water, pure and flawless."*

The Dao transcends form and name, inherently without shape or image. Yet when it generates the singular *qi*, it seems possible to describe. However, this true unity of *qi* is subtle and elusive, manifesting in the formless and appearing in the imageless—beyond all conjecture or speculation of the mind. Thus it is said, *"The form and image of the Dao—true unity is hard to depict."*

This true unity of Water is the single point of *yinqiao* in the Central Palace, the so-called "Supreme Unity containing the true *qi*." Combined, it is one *qi*; divided, it becomes two substances; further divided, it becomes the Four Images and Five Phases. When they interact, the Five Phases transform entirely within the center. Yet Wood remains in the East, Metal in the West, Fire in the South, and Water in the North—each abiding in its proper place. Hence it is said, *"Though it changes and spreads, each abides in its own place."*

This section declares that the true unity of Water is indeed the foundation of the Elixir. As *The Mirror for Compounding the Medicine* states, *"The Lead of the Water Realm is but a single flavor."* If the scholar understands the principle of gathering the Five and uniting the Four, merging dualities into oneness, the *yinqiao* will form, and the Sacred Embryo will take shape. It resembles an egg, where white and black correspond, spanning an inch in all directions—this is the initial stage. The four limbs and five viscera, along with sinews and bones, are all present. After ten months, it emerges from its womb. Its bones are supple enough to coil, its flesh smooth as maltose.

This passage particularly reveals the form of the Dharma-body. When the Sacred Embryo first congeals, a single spark of original spirit lies hidden in the chamber of spirit, indistinct and undivided, like primordial chaos before the separation of darkness and light—akin to the state of an egg. Thus it is said, *"It resembles an egg, where white and black correspond."* Within the chamber of spirit, the space is perfectly square and round, exactly an inch in diameter. The Dharma-body dwells within, growing and flourishing, just as an infant in the mother’s womb—hence, *"spanning an inch in all directions, this is the initial stage."*

To nurture the true embryo, one must proceed from the subtle to the manifest. First, an image forms; then, a shape. The four limbs, five viscera, sinews, bones, and joints—all become complete, fully formed yet minute. Thus it is said, *"The four limbs and five viscera, along with sinews and bones, are all present."* Know that the Four Images and Five Phases envelop the Dharma-body like the four limbs and five viscera; as the Dharma-body gradually solidifies, it resembles sinews and bones—yet it is not truly tangible. When the nurturing is complete, after ten months the embryo is fully formed. The infant leaps forth from the Kun furnace, ascending into the Qian cauldron. From here, the furnace and cauldron are reset, and Heaven and Earth are recreated—ushering in a new transformation. Only then does one’s Dharma-body connect with Heaven and Earth, merging with the Great Void. Thus it is said, *"After ten months, it emerges from its womb,"* taking on the appearance of supple bones and flesh smooth as maltose.

This passage describes the form of the Dharma-body as sharing the same creative process as the physical body receiving *qi* in the mother’s womb. Yet while the natural course produces a human, the reverse course yields the Elixir—distinguishing the sacred from the ordinary. This chapter is the first crucial threshold of nurturing nature, corresponding to the previous section on the mutual interaction of the two orifices.

**Chapter Twenty-One: The Mutual Resonance of the Two Qi**

A burning-mirror draws fire—without the sun, it cannot glow.
A moon-pearl gathers dew—without stars or moon, how could it yield water?
The two *qi* are profound and distant, yet their resonance still connects—
How much more so when near, stored within the heart and chest?

Yin and Yang pair with the sun and moon; Water and Fire serve as their signs.
This chapter speaks of the mutual resonance of the *qi* of Water and Fire through like attracting like.

The previous chapter described the soul and spirit as mutual dwellings—these are the two substances, Water and Fire. The Dao of the Golden Elixir takes the sun and moon as its body and Water and Fire as its function. In essence, they interpenetrate; in function, they interact. Without Water and Fire, the sun and moon have no means to manifest their essence; without the sun and moon, Water and Fire have no source for their function. Whether drawn from the body or from external things, the principle is the same.

The burning-mirror is a fire-pearl, shaped like a bronze mirror, solid in its center—symbolizing the single Yang within Kan. This object embodies the fiery essence of the Great Yang. Thus, people use it to draw fire, but it must face the sun to succeed. This is because the spark of true Yang is originally the light of the sun’s soul. The sun is the gathering place of light, while the burning-mirror is the summoner of light. Drawing fire with fire—how could it not be effective? Hence it is said, *"A burning-mirror draws fire—without the sun, it cannot glow."*

The moon-pearl is a pearl from a clam, hollow in its center—symbolizing the single Yin within Li. This object embodies the watery essence of the Great Yin. Thus, people use it to gather water, but it must face the moon to succeed. This is because the spark of true Yin is originally the essence of the moon’s spirit. The moon is the repository of essence, while the moon-pearl is the gatherer of essence. Drawing water with water—how could it not respond? Hence it is said, *"A moon-pearl gathers dew—without stars or moon, how could it yield water?"* This is the principle of the mutual interaction of Kan and Li.

The sun and moon in the sky and Water and Fire in the world are separated by countless miles—truly profound and distant. Yet they resonate across barriers, like a magnet attracting iron. This is because like naturally draws like, so the two *qi* spontaneously resonate and connect.

chunks.original_text: 远取诸物，无情者尚且相感，如此矧（shěn况且/亦），近取诸身，有情之真水真火切在方吋之间，至虚至灵，一呼即应，两弦真炁有不相感化者乎？ 所以离中真水往而流戊，坎中真火来而就己，假法象而采太阴之精，立鼎器以聚太阳之炁，自然同类相从，结成鄞鄂。 盖真阴真阳互藏其宅，便是吾身之日月； 日光月精相胥为用，便是吾身之水火； 其间采取感召全仗中黄真意，即吾身阳燧方诸之妙用也。 故曰“阴阳配日月，水火为效征”。 此章专言二物相感，同气相求，发明大易性情宗旨。 盖寂然不动，性之体也； 感而遂通，情之用也。 离之情常在于北，坎之情常在于南，此日月之所以合璧，而水火之所以交也。 离中真水复归于北，坎中真火复归于南，此乾坤之所以还元，而鄞鄂之所以立也。 周易上经首乾坤，取其定位以立体也。 下经首咸恒，取其交感以致用也。 泽上山下，其卦为咸，孔子翼之曰“二气感应以相与”，又曰“天地感而万物化生”，可见天地间只此二气，顺而相感则生物，逆而相感则成丹，况兑艮二体正应上下两弦，即兑艮交感之用以还乾坤不易之体，岂不犹阳燧方诸之相取者乎？ 噫！ 此人人具足之真易也。

Drawing from distant things, even the insentient still resonate—how much more so when drawing from the body, where the true Water and true Fire of the sentient lie mere inches apart, utterly void yet supremely numinous, responding in an instant to a single breath? Could the true *qi* of the two celestial arcs fail to resonate and transform?

Thus, the true Water within Li flows forth to meet Wu, while the true Fire within Kan comes to join Ji. By employing symbolic methods to gather the essence of the Great Yin and erecting the crucible to collect the *qi* of the Great Yang, like naturally follows like, coalescing into the *yinqie*. For when true Yin and true Yang mutually abide in their dwelling, they become the sun and moon within one’s own body; when the sunlight and moon essence reciprocally engage, they become the Water and Fire within one’s own body. The gathering and summoning between them rely entirely on the true intent of the Central Yellow—this is the wondrous function of the yang-sundial and moon-pearl within one’s own body. Hence it is said, *"Yin and Yang pair with the sun and moon; Water and Fire serve as their proof."*

This chapter focuses on the mutual resonance of the two things and the affinity of like *qi*, elucidating the fundamental principle of *Xing* and *Qing* in the *Great Change*. For stillness without movement is the essence of *Xing*; response leading to communion is the function of *Qing*. The *Qing* of Li ever resides in the North, while the *Qing* of Kan ever resides in the South—this is how the sun and moon unite as a bi-disc and how Water and Fire intermingle. When the true Water within Li returns to the North and the true Fire within Kan returns to the South, this is how Qian and Kun revert to their origin and how the *yinqie* is established.

The *Upper Canon* of the *Zhouyi* begins with Qian and Kun, taking their fixed positions to establish the essence. The *Lower Canon* begins with *Xian* and *Heng*, taking their interaction to achieve function. The hexagram *Xian* depicts a marsh above a mountain, and Confucius’ commentary on it states, *"The two *qi* resonate and commune,"* and further, *"Heaven and Earth respond, and the myriad things are transformed and born."* Clearly, the world contains only these two *qi*: when they flow in harmony and resonate, they give life to beings; when they flow in reverse and resonate, they form the Elixir. Moreover, the two trigrams Dui and Gen precisely correspond to the upper and lower celestial arcs—employing the interactive function of Dui and Gen to restore the unchanging essence of Qian and Kun is no different from the mutual gathering of the yang-sundial and moon-pearl.

Alas! This is the true *Yi* inherent in every person.

chunks.original_text: 关键三宝章第二十二章明从旧（疑为“章名从旧”四字） 耳目口三宝，闭塞勿发通。 真人潜深渊，浮游守规中。 旋曲以视听，开阖皆合同，为己之枢辖，动静不竭穷。 离炁纳荣卫，坎乃不用聪，兑合不以谈，希言顺鸿蒙。 三者既关键，缓体处空房。 委志归虚无，无念以为常。 证难以推移，心专不纵横，寝寐神相抱，觉悟候存亡。 颜色浸以润，骨节益坚强。 辟却众阴邪，然后立正阳。 修之不辍休，庶炁云雨行。 淫淫若春泽，液液若解氷，从头流达足，究竟复上升，往来洞无极，怫怫被谷中。 反者道之验，弱者德之柄。 耘锄宿污秽，细微得调畅。 浊者清之路，昏久则昭明。 此章言关键三宝，内真外应，乃养性之要功也。 耳目口三宝，闭塞勿发通。 真人潜深渊，浮游守规中。 此节统言关键三宝之要道也。 修道之士有内三宝有外三宝，元精元气元神内三宝也，耳目口外三宝也； 欲得内三宝还真，全在外三宝不漏，《阴符经》所谓“九窍之邪，在乎三要”是也。 下手之初必须屏聪黜明，谨闭兑口，真元方不外漏，故曰“耳目口三宝，闭塞勿发通”。 外窍不漏，元神内存，前后会合，中间有一无位真人潜藏深渊之中，深渊乃北极太渊，天心之所居，即元关一窍也。 元关在天地之间，上下四方之正中，虚悬一穴，其大无外，其小无内，谓之规中，中有主宰，谓之真人，守而勿失，谓之抱一，然其妙诀全在不动不怠，勿助勿忘，有浮游之象，故曰“真人潜深渊，浮游守规中”。 此四句乃养性之要功，一章之纲领也。 旋曲以视听，开阖皆合同，为己之枢辖，动静不竭穷。 离炁纳荣卫，坎乃不用聪，兑合不以谈，希言顺鸿蒙。 此节详言三宝关键功夫。 坎属水，是为元门； 离属火，是为牝户； 兑为口，内应方吋； 学人入室之时，当收视返听，转顺为逆，其门户之一开一阖，皆与元牝内窍相应。 故曰“旋曲以视听，开阖皆合同”。 坎中纳戊，离中纳己，戊土属阳主动，离土属阴主静； 离中一阴体虽静，而实则易动，憧憬往来，不可禁止，惟赖坎中真阳出而钤（qián见“钤”）制之，若门之有枢，车之有辖，庶乎一开一阖，动静各有其时，而元炁不致耗竭矣。 故曰“为己之枢辖，动静不竭穷”。 元窍中先天祖炁本来鸿蒙未剖，惜乎前发乎离，以泄其明； 后发乎坎，以泄其聪； 中发乎兑，以开其门； 三者俱散而不收，先天之炁所存者，几何哉？ 必也默默垂帘，频频逆听，则坎离之炁不泄矣。 故曰“离炁纳荣卫，坎乃不用聪”。 括蘘内守，混沌忘言，则兑口之炁不泄矣。 故曰“兑合不以谈，希言顺鸿蒙”。 即所谓“耳目口三宝，闭塞勿发通”者也。 此中秘密全在“口”字，此“口”是元关一窍，吞吐乾坤，因天机不可尽泄，姑取兑象，非世人饮食之口也，必须真师指示方知其妙。 三者既关键，缓体处空房。 委志归虚无，无念以为常。 证难以推移，心专不纵横。 寝寐神相抱，觉悟候存亡。 此节详言潜渊守中功夫。 耳目口三者既已关键严密，一毫不泄，则我之真人自然不扰不杂，优游于深渊之中，此中空空洞洞，别无一物，有若空房然，故曰“三者既关键，缓体处空房”。 先天一炁原从虚无中来，必委致其志，虚以待之，至于六根大定，一念不生，方得相应；

**Chapter Twenty-Two: The Key to the Three Treasures**

The three treasures—ear, eye, and mouth—
Seal them tight, let no passage through.
The true person hides in the deep abyss,
Drifting and roaming, guarding the center’s rule.

Turning and bending to see and hear,
Opening and closing, all in accord.
They serve as the pivot and linchpin for the self,
In movement and stillness, never exhausted.

*Li*’s *qi* receives *rong* and *wei*,
*Kan* then ceases its hearing.
*Dui* closes, not with speech,
Silent words follow the primordial chaos.

Once these three are secured,
Relax the body in an empty chamber.
Entrust the will to emptiness and nothingness,
Take no-thought as the constant state.

Proof is unshaken by change,
The mind focused, not scattered.
In sleep, spirit and self embrace,
In waking, await the signs of presence and absence.

The complexion gradually moistens,
The bones and joints grow stronger.
Repelling all yin evils,
Only then is true yang established.

Practice without cease,
And the *qi* of clouds and rain will flow.
Gentle as spring rain,
Fluid as melting ice,
From head to foot it streams,
Then rises again in fullness,
Coming and going through the boundless void,
Pervading the valleys with subtle breath.

Reversion is the Dao’s verification,
Weakness is virtue’s handle.
Cultivate and clear the long-accumulated filth,
In the finest details, harmony is achieved.
The turbid is the path to clarity,
Prolonged darkness yields to brightness.

This chapter speaks of the key to the three treasures,
Inner reality matching outer response—
The essential work of nurturing one’s nature.

The three treasures—ear, eye, and mouth—
Seal them tight, let no passage through.
The true person hides in the deep abyss,
Drifting and roaming, guarding the center’s rule.

This section summarizes the essential Dao of securing the three treasures.
The cultivator of the Dao possesses inner and outer three treasures:
The inner three are original essence, original *qi*, and original spirit;
The outer three are ear, eye, and mouth.
To return the inner three treasures to truth,
All depends on the outer three not leaking—
As the *Yinfu Jing* states, “The nine orifices’ deviations lie in the three essentials.”
At the outset, one must withdraw hearing and dismiss sight,
Carefully seal the *Dui* mouth,
So the true origin does not leak outward.
Thus it is said: “The three treasures—ear, eye, and mouth—
Seal them tight, let no passage through.”

With the outer orifices unbreached,
The original spirit abides within.
Front and back converge,
And in the center, a positionless true person hides in the deep abyss.
The deep abyss is the North Culmen’s Great Abyss,
The dwelling of the celestial heart—
The original pass, the one orifice.
The original pass lies at the center of heaven and earth,
The exact middle of the four directions above and below,
A suspended cavity, boundless in vastness,
Infinitesimal in smallness—
This is called the center’s rule.
Within it is a master,
Called the true person.
Guard it without losing,
Called embracing the One.
Yet its subtlety lies entirely in non-action and non-idleness,
Neither forcing nor forgetting,
Possessing the image of drifting—
Thus it is said: “The true person hides in the deep abyss,
Drifting and roaming, guarding the center’s rule.”
These four lines are the essential work of nurturing one’s nature,
The guiding principle of the entire chapter.

Turning and bending to see and hear,
Opening and closing, all in accord.
They serve as the pivot and linchpin for the self,
In movement and stillness, never exhausted.

*Kan* belongs to water, the original gate;
*Li* belongs to fire, the female portal;
*Dui* is the mouth, corresponding internally to the square inch.
When the adept enters the chamber,
They should withdraw sight and return hearing,
Turning the usual into the reverse.
The opening and closing of these gates
All correspond to the inner orifice of the original female.
Thus it is said: “Turning and bending to see and hear,
Opening and closing, all in accord.”

Within *Kan* is received *wu*,
Within *Li* is received *ji*.
*Wu*-earth belongs to yang and governs movement;
*Li*-earth belongs to yin and governs stillness.
Though *Li*’s one yin body is still,
In truth it is easily moved,
Restless and shifting, uncontrollable.
Only by relying on the true yang emerging from *Kan* to restrain it—
Like a door’s pivot, a chariot’s linchpin—
Can opening and closing each have their time,
Movement and stillness each their proper moment,
And the original *qi* not be exhausted.
Thus it is said: “They serve as the pivot and linchpin for the self,
In movement and stillness, never exhausted.”

Within the original orifice, the primordial ancestral *qi*
Originally was undivided chaos.
Alas, it first emerges from *Li*, leaking its brightness;
Then from *Kan*, leaking its hearing;
And from *Dui*, opening its gate.
All three scatter without return—
How much of the primordial *qi* remains?
Only by silently lowering the inner screen,
Repeatedly reversing hearing,
Can the *qi* of *Kan* and *Li* not leak.
Thus it is said: “*Li*’s *qi* receives *rong* and *wei*,
*Kan* then ceases its hearing.”
Guard within, forget speech,
So the *qi* of the *Dui* mouth does not leak.
Thus it is said: “*Dui* closes, not with speech,
Silent words follow the primordial chaos.”
This is what is meant by “The three treasures—ear, eye, and mouth—
Seal them tight, let no passage through.”

The secret here lies entirely in the “mouth.”
This “mouth” is the original pass, the one orifice,
Swallowing and spitting forth heaven and earth.
Since the celestial mechanism cannot be fully revealed,
It is provisionally taken as the *Dui* image—
Not the mouth of eating and drinking in the world.
Only with a true teacher’s guidance can its subtlety be known.

Once these three are secured,
Relax the body in an empty chamber.
Entrust the will to emptiness and nothingness,
Take no-thought as the constant state.

This section details the work of hiding in the abyss and guarding the center.
Once the three—ear, eye, and mouth—are securely sealed,
Not a single thread leaks,
Then one’s true person naturally remains undisturbed and unconfused,
Roaming freely in the deep abyss.
Within, it is empty and vast,
Devoid of all things,
Like an empty chamber.
Thus it is said: “Once these three are secured,
Relax the body in an empty chamber.”

The primordial one *qi* originally comes from emptiness and nothingness.
One must entrust the will to it,
Awaiting it in emptiness.
Only when the six roots are fully stabilized,
Not a single thought arising,
Can resonance be achieved.

chunks.translated_text:
Yet this so-called "no-thought" is but constant responsiveness within stillness, never straying beyond the proper measure—far from the dull inertia of wood or stone. This "thought of no-thought" is the true thought; when true thought stands ever-present before one, only then may the primordial one *qi* be attained, and the moment of obtaining the medicine arrive. Thus it is said: "Entrust the will to emptiness and nothingness, take no-thought as the constant state."

This matter is possessed by all, and in itself is no difficult attainment—like raising a pole and seeing its shadow. Yet the difficulty people face in attaining it lies precisely in the mind’s will not being concentrated, shifting moment by moment, scattering in a hundred directions, so that they gaze across the ocean and turn back. If, when entering the chamber, the mind’s will is single and unshifting, free from the malady of scattering, then it may be grasped in a single breath—what difficulty remains in attaining it? Thus it is said: "Attainment is difficult to shift; the mind, concentrated, does not scatter."

Once this mind remains unmoved, throughout the twelve hours—whether in motion, stillness, sitting, or lying—it never strays from the proper measure. Even when retiring at dusk to rest, as the primordial spirit naturally embraces the primordial *qi*, like a seed of fire within a furnace, one must remain ever awake and ever aware, inwardly illuminating the mind to observe the ebb and flow within the proper measure and to watch for the presence or absence of the true seed. Thus it is said: "In sleep, spirit embraces spirit; in wakefulness, one watches for its presence or absence." With such attentiveness, how can one fear the golden elixir will not coalesce or the true person fail to appear? This is the discipline of "the true person hidden in the deep abyss, floating and roaming while guarding the proper measure."

The complexion becomes increasingly moist,
The bones and joints grow ever stronger.
All yin evils are repelled,
And then the true yang is established.
If cultivation is unceasing,
The *qi* will course like clouds and rain.
Gentle as spring’s nourishing rain,
Flowing like melting ice,
From the head it streams down to the feet,
Then ultimately ascends again.
Coming and going through the boundless void,
Pervading the valleys with a subtle presence.

This section speaks of the signs of elixir formation. When the body and spirit, originally inseparable, receive the true seed, the inner and outer respond as one: naturally, the complexion becomes moist and radiant, the bones and joints grow strong, and the postnatal yin evils are expelled, establishing the primordial true yang *qi*. For within the body, all is yin evil; when the primordial yang *qi* arrives, yin evils naturally cannot remain. If cultivation is unceasing, its effects are divine: throughout the nine orifices, eight vessels, three hundred and sixty bones and joints, and eighty-four thousand pores, the great harmony of primordial *qi* circulates. One sees it move like clouds, descend like rain, moisten like spring’s nourishment, and flow like melting ice—from the Kunlun peak it descends to the feet, then from the Yongquan point it ascends back to the head, penetrating head and feet, coming and going through the boundless void without obstruction. For in heaven and earth, mountains, rivers, earth, and stone are all blocked and impassable, while only the hollow heavens and empty valleys are interconnected. The human body is the same: flesh and bones are blocked and impassable, while only the primordial apertures and empty valleys, vessel upon vessel, are interconnected, resembling the hollow heavens of creation. The primordial *qi* comes and goes, boundlessly pervading the empty valleys. Thus it is said: "Coming and going through the boundless void, subtly pervading the valleys."

This resembles the earlier passage: "The yellow center gradually opens its principle, moistening and nourishing the skin." Both describe the natural signs of the golden elixir.

Reversal is the verification of the Dao,
Weakness is the handle of virtue.
Cultivate to clear long-standing filth,
And in the finest details, harmony is achieved.
The turbid is the path to clarity,
Prolonged darkness leads to illumination.

This concludes by speaking of the golden elixir’s transcendence of the ordinary. What is reversal? The common Dao proceeds in accord, while the elixir Dao proceeds in reversal—overturning the Mysterious Female, embracing the One without separation, only then can one return to the root and restore life. Is this not "reversal is the verification of the Dao"? What is weakness? The strong and rigid are followers of death, while the soft and weak are followers of life. Concentrating *qi* to attain softness, becoming like an infant, naturally places the handle in one’s grasp. Is this not "weakness is the handle of virtue"?

Moreover, when yin evils are repelled, all long-standing filth within the body is thoroughly cultivated and removed. Once true yang is established, the primordial *qi* penetrates, and even the finest details are harmonized without obstruction. When the golden elixir first forms, the pulse halts and *qi* settles, returning to primordial chaos, re-entering the womb—this is the great death of the body. After a long time, one revives beyond all expectation, directly witnessing the original face, naturally attaining pure clarity, perfect wisdom, and all-pervading illumination, so that heaven and earth become a crystal palace. Thus it is said: "The turbid is the path to clarity, prolonged darkness leads to illumination."

The previous section spoke of the marvels of form; this section speaks of the marvels of spirit. Only when both form and spirit are marvelous can one unite with the Dao in truth. This chapter focuses on securing the three treasures, which is the first step in guarding the center and embracing the One—nurturing inner nature. It corresponds to the earlier chapter on refining the self and establishing the foundation.

**Appendix:**
Bao Yi Zi said: "When the ears do not listen, the Kan water within settles; when the eyes do not see, the Li fire within is nurtured; when the mouth does not speak, the Dui metal does not sound. Once these three are closed, the true person roams freely within."

He also said: "When the seven gates are returned, one nearly forgets life; all pulses sink, form and *qi* dissolve, strength fails to support, and one becomes as dull and turbid as if drunk. This is the verification of the Dao and the handle of virtue. Darkness is the foundation of brightness, turbidity is the source of clarity. From this point onward, perfect illumination, empty penetration, and spiritual communication all begin from darkness and turbidity."

Yu Yu Wu said: "Reversal means turning back. The verification of elixir cultivation lies in extreme emptiness and profound stillness, merging with heaven and earth, then the primordial *qi* returns from the first yang."

**Chapter Twenty-Three: The Chapter on Heterodox Schools Achieving Nothing (Title follows tradition)**

The world delights in petty arts,
Not discerning the Dao’s depth or shallowness.
Abandoning the true to follow deviant paths,
They seek swift results but meet obstruction and blockage.
Like the blind without a staff to lean on,
Or the deaf listening to gong and shang notes,
Diving into water to hunt pheasants and hares,
Or scaling mountains to seek fish and dragons,
Planting wheat yet hoping for millet,
Or wielding a compass to draw a square—
They exhaust their strength and labor their spirits,
Yet through the years see no achievement.

To know the method of *fushi* (internal alchemy),
It is most concise and not cumbersome.
This chapter decisively declares the futility of heterodox schools.

Those who study the Dao must first understand:
The Dao and mere techniques differ as heaven from earth.
The complete cultivation of *xing* (nature) and *ming* (life),
Returning to the boundless, is called the Great Dao.
A single mechanism, a single trick,
Incapable of self-salvation, is called a petty art.

The Great Dao of the Golden Elixir is hard to encounter yet easy to accomplish;
All heterodox schools and petty arts are easy to encounter yet hard to accomplish.
Alas! The foolish people of the world have minds choked with weeds:
Not only do they fail to distinguish depth from shallowness,
Their vision blurred,
But they also cannot discern the true from the deviant.
Often they turn their backs on light to grope in darkness,
Abandoning the true to follow the false.
Originally seeking swift results,
They instead meet obstruction and blockage,
Forever severing the path to the Dao—
Is this not lamentable?

Unknowing that the precelestial *xing* and *ming* transcend form and instrument,
They mistakenly grasp at postcelestial essence and *qi*,
Groping within the body,
Lost and without trace,
Tossed about by others’ delusions,
Utterly without discernment—
This is like the blind without a staff to lean on,
Or the deaf listening to gong and shang notes.

Failing to realize that precelestial yin and yang are of the same kind as oneself,
They guess them to be worldly men and women,
Seeking them externally,
Drifting into licentiousness and depravity,
Harming life and corrupting virtue—
Nothing is more grievous.
This is like entering water to hunt pheasants and hares,
Or scaling mountains to seek fish and dragons.

Not considering that precelestial lead and mercury are originally without substance or form,
They go about burning thatch and playing with fire,
Refining mercury to transmute copper,
Deceiving and bewildering the foolish,
Ruining themselves and destroying their families—
This is like planting wheat yet hoping for millet,
Or wielding a compass while vainly seeking a square.

These heterodox schools expend a lifetime of effort,
Toiling year after year,
Yet in old age achieve nothing.
Instead, they slander the ancestral masters as liars,
Unknowing that the method of the Golden Elixir’s *fushi*
Is most simple and essential:
With *youwei* (action) to trace back to the origin,
And *wuwei* (non-action) to grasp the end,
Its function is one with the creation of heaven and earth.
Even the dullest of men, upon obtaining it,
Instantly ascends to sagehood—
How can it be mentioned in the same breath as heterodox schools and petty arts?

This discussion of the faults of heterodox schools merely outlines the general points.
To exhaustively examine them:
The Chan school has ninety-six kinds of external paths,
The Yuan teachings have three thousand six hundred heterodox schools—
A thousand differences, ten thousand divergences,
Impossible to enumerate fully.
Thus, the Patriarch of Zhengyang composed the *Song of the True Dao*,
The Perfected of Cuixu wrote the *Luofu Lament*,
And extending to Li Qing’an’s *Nine Grades Discourse*
And Chen Guanwu’s *Song of Resolving Delusion*—
All meticulously detail the errors of heterodox schools and external paths,
To awaken the deaf and blind of the world.
Alas! The world does not awaken,
And these deluded traditions continue to spread,
Increasing without end—
Truly pitiable.

The above merely sketches the broad strokes.
One should select the essential sayings of the perfected,
And compile a separate work, *Guide for the Lost*,
To be studied together with like-minded seekers.

chunks.original_text: 此卷专言伏食，而御政养性已寓其中，义同上篇。 流珠金华章第二十四 太阳流珠，常欲去人。 卒得金华，转而相因，化为白液，凝而至坚。 金华先倡，有倾之间，解化为水，马齿瓓玕，阳乃往和，情性自然。 迫促时阴，拘畜禁门，慈母养育，孝子报恩，严父施令，教勅子孙。 五行错王，相据以生，火性销金，金伐木荣。 三五为一，天地至精，可以口诀，难以书传。 子当右转，午乃东旋，卯酉界隔，主客二名。 龙呼于虎，虎吸龙精，两相饮食，俱使合併，遂相衔咽（xian yan），咀嚼相吞。 荧惑守西，太白经天，杀气所临，何有不倾。 狸犬守鼠，鸟雀畏鹯（zhān），各得其性，何敢有声？ 此章言木性金情自相交会，以成伏食之功也。 太阳流珠，常欲去人。 卒得金华，转而相因，化为白液，凝而至坚。 此节言两物之性情合而成金丹也。 先天之体为性命，乾坤是也； 后天之用为性情，坎离是也； 自乾坤破为坎离，性情之用着而性命之体隐，顺之则成凡矣。 惟坎离复交为乾坤，因性情之用以还性命之体，逆之则成圣矣。 至于后天坎离中又分体用，以真阴真阳为体，体属水火； 以两弦之气为用，用属金木； 不可不辨。 干属太阳真性，本来寂然不动，只因交入坤中一阴，性转为情，遂成离中木汞，自此阴精用事，离光顺流向外，恍惚不定，有流珠之象； 干既成离，其中一阳走入坤宫，坤属太阴元命，既得干中一阳，命转作性，遂成坎中金铅，此点金炁精华，只在坎水中潜藏，杳冥不测，有金华之象。 离中灵物刻刻流转，本易走而难捉，捉之愈急，去之愈速，赖得坎中一点真铅逆转以制之，真汞一见真铅，才不飞走。 故曰“太阳流珠，常欲去人。 卒得金华，转而相因”。 铅入汞中，汞赖铅之拘钤（qián），铅亦得汞之变化，两物会入黄房，合成一炁，其炁先液而后凝，故曰“化为白液，凝而至坚”。 白者金色，至坚者金性也。 盖金来归性，已结而成丹矣。 此通章之纲领也。 金华先倡，有倾之间，解化为水，马齿瓓玕，阳乃往和，情性自然。 此节言两物交併自相倡和也。 坎男主倡，离女主和，坎中一阳，本自难于出炉，及其时至而出也。 只在一弹指间，故曰“金华先倡，有倾之间”； 水中生金，金中复能化水，盖金华之液即真一之水也。 絪缊活动，无质生质，渐渐坚凝，有若马齿瓓玕之状，故曰“解化为水，马齿瓓玕”。 坎中之金液既升，离中之木液乃从而和之，一东一西，间隔已久，幸得真意勾引相会黄房，木性爱金，金情恋木，一倡一和，出于性情之自然，非人力可强而致，故曰“阳乃往和，情性自然”。 阳即上文太阳流珠，以其外阳内阴，易于逐物流走，主和而不主倡，惟与金华之真阳相匹为夫妇，方不流走，此时已转为真阴，故有妇道颠倒之妙，不可不知。 迫促时阴，拘畜禁门，慈母养育，孝子报恩，严父施令，教勅子孙。 此节言拘制两物会中宫而产真种也。 坎中之金华既升，离中之流珠即降，两弦之炁相交只在一时，时不可失，当以真意迫促之，两物相交，正当虚危中间，此时宜禁闭地户，翕聚真炁，不可一毫泄漏，故曰“迫促时阴，拘畜禁门”； 真种既归土釜，全赖中宫坤母为之温养哺育，始而母去顾子，如雌鸡之伏卵，时时相抱，既而子来恋母，若慈鸟之反哺，刻刻不离，故曰“慈母养育，孝子报恩”；

This scroll focuses exclusively on *fushi* (subduing and ingesting), wherein the governance of governance and the nurturing of nature are already implicit—its meaning aligns with the preceding section.

**Chapter Twenty-Four: Flowing Pearl and Golden Flower**

The flowing pearl of the Great Yang ever seeks to depart from man.
Suddenly obtaining the golden flower, it turns and interrelates,
Transforming into a white liquid, congealing to utmost firmness.

The golden flower takes the lead; in but a moment,
It dissolves and transforms into water—jade-like horse’s teeth,
The Yang then moves to harmonize, nature and emotion in spontaneity.

Pressing upon the timely Yin, restraining and enclosing the forbidden gate,
The compassionate mother nurtures, the filial son repays kindness,
The stern father issues commands, instructing and admonishing descendants.

The Five Phases vie for dominance, each relying on the other to arise;
Fire’s nature melts metal, metal fells wood to flourish.

The Three and Five unite as one—the utmost essence of Heaven and Earth.
This may be transmitted orally, yet is difficult to convey in writing.

You must turn to the right, at noon rotate eastward;
Mao and You form the boundary, host and guest assume their names.

The dragon calls to the tiger, the tiger inhales the dragon’s essence,
Both feed upon each other, compelled to merge,
Then interlock and swallow, chewing and devouring one another.

When Yinghuo guards the west and Taibai traverses the heavens,
Wherever the killing qi descends, what can remain unoverturned?
The foxhound guards the rat, the sparrow fears the kestrel—
Each fulfills its nature; how dare they utter a sound?

This chapter speaks of the wood-nature and metal-emotion spontaneously uniting to accomplish the work of *fushi*.

The flowing pearl of the Great Yang ever seeks to depart from man.
Suddenly obtaining the golden flower, it turns and interrelates,
Transforming into a white liquid, congealing to utmost firmness.

This passage describes the union of the natures and emotions of two substances to form the golden elixir.

The primordial body is nature and life—this is Qian and Kun.
The post-celestial function is nature and emotion—this is Kan and Li.
Since Qian and Kun shattered into Kan and Li,
The function of nature and emotion became manifest while the body of nature and life receded.
Following this, one becomes ordinary.
Only when Kan and Li re-unite as Qian and Kun,
Using the function of nature and emotion to restore the body of nature and life,
Reversing this, one becomes sagely.

Within the post-celestial Kan and Li, body and function further divide:
True Yin and True Yang constitute the body, which pertains to water and fire;
The qi of the two meridians constitutes the function, which pertains to metal and wood.
This distinction must not be confused.

Qian pertains to the True Nature of the Great Yang, originally quiescent and unmoving.
Yet upon merging with Kun’s single Yin, nature transforms into emotion,
Becoming the wood-mercury within Li.
From this point, Yin essence prevails,
Li’s light flows outward in compliance,
Flickering and unstable, assuming the form of a flowing pearl.
Once Qian becomes Li, its single Yang enters the Kun palace.
Kun pertains to the Primordial Life of the Great Yin.
Upon receiving Qian’s single Yang, life transforms into nature,
Becoming the metal-lead within Kan.
This speck of golden qi’s essence lies hidden within Kan’s water,
Profound and unfathomable, assuming the form of the golden flower.

Li’s numinous substance constantly circulates, inherently prone to flee and difficult to grasp.
The more urgently one seizes it, the swifter it departs.
Fortunately, Kan’s single True Lead reverses its course to restrain it.
Upon encountering True Lead, True Mercury no longer flees.
Thus it is said: “The flowing pearl of the Great Yang ever seeks to depart from man.
Suddenly obtaining the golden flower, it turns and interrelates.”

When lead enters mercury, mercury relies on lead’s restraint,
While lead also gains mercury’s transformative power.
The two substances meet in the Yellow Chamber, merging into a single qi.
This qi first becomes liquid, then congeals,
Hence it is said: “Transforming into a white liquid, congealing to utmost firmness.”
White is the color of metal; utmost firmness is the nature of metal.
When metal returns to nature, the elixir is already formed.
This is the guiding principle of the entire chapter.

The golden flower takes the lead; in but a moment,
It dissolves and transforms into water—jade-like horse’s teeth.
The Yang then moves to harmonize, nature and emotion in spontaneity.

This passage describes the two substances spontaneously uniting and harmonizing in turn.
The Kan male takes the lead, the Li female responds.
Kan’s single Yang is inherently difficult to extract from the furnace,
Yet when the time arrives, it emerges in but a finger-snap.
Thus it is said: “The golden flower takes the lead; in but a moment.”
Metal born within water can itself transform into water—
The liquid of the golden flower is the True One’s water.
Vibrant and dynamic, formless yet generating form,
It gradually solidifies, resembling the jade-like teeth of a horse.
Thus it is said: “Dissolves and transforms into water—jade-like horse’s teeth.”

Once Kan’s golden liquid ascends, Li’s wood liquid follows to harmonize with it.
East and west, long separated,
Fortunately, True Intention draws them to meet in the Yellow Chamber.
Wood-nature loves metal, metal-emotion yearns for wood.
One leads, the other responds, arising from the spontaneity of nature and emotion,
Not something that can be forced by human effort.
Thus it is said: “The Yang then moves to harmonize, nature and emotion in spontaneity.”
The Yang here refers to the flowing pearl of the Great Yang mentioned above.
Externally Yang yet internally Yin, it readily follows things and flees,
Responding rather than leading.
Only when paired with the True Yang of the golden flower as husband and wife
Does it cease to flee.
At this point, it has transformed into True Yin,
Thus possessing the marvel of the wife’s path overturned—
This must not be overlooked.

Pressing upon the timely Yin, restraining and enclosing the forbidden gate,
The compassionate mother nurtures, the filial son repays kindness,
The stern father issues commands, instructing and admonishing descendants.

This passage describes restraining the two substances to meet in the Central Palace and produce the true seed.
Once Kan’s golden flower ascends, Li’s flowing pearl descends.
The qi of the two meridians unite in a single moment—
The time must not be lost.
One must press upon it with True Intention.
When the two substances unite, precisely at the midpoint between Xu and Wei,
One should seal the earthly gate and gather the true qi,
Allowing not the slightest leakage.
Thus it is said: “Pressing upon the timely Yin, restraining and enclosing the forbidden gate.”
Once the true seed returns to the earthen cauldron,
It relies entirely on the Kun mother of the Central Palace for warmth and nourishment.
Initially, the mother attends to the child, like a hen brooding her eggs, constantly embracing them.
Later, the child yearns for the mother, like the kind bird returning food, never parting for a moment.
Thus it is said: “The compassionate mother nurtures, the filial son repays kindness.”

All meticulously detail the errors of heterodox schools and external paths,
To awaken the deaf and blind of the world.
Alas! The world does not awaken,

chunks.original_text: 真种既存中宫，外面最要严谨堤防，牢镇八门，环匝关闭，不可一毫放松，譬如子当幼小之时，养育固愿慈母，教勅全仗严父，故曰“严父施令，教勅子孙”。 慈母喻文火，在神室中温养； 严父喻武火，在门户间堤防； 孝子喻真种，即金华流珠两物所结成者。 自迫促时阴至此，俱属金丹作用，只在一刻中。 五行错王，相据以生，火性销金，金伐木荣。 三五为一，天地至精，可以口诀，难以书传。 此节言作丹之时，五行颠倒之妙也。 常道之五行俱从顺生，如金生水，木生火之类，顺流无制，必至精炁耗散，去死不远，生机转作杀机，所谓生者死之根也。 丹道之五行全用逆转，如流珠本是木龙，却从离火中取出； 金华本是金虎，却从坎水中取出； 水火互藏，金木颠倒，方得归根复命，劫劫长存，杀机转作生机，所谓死者生之根也； 故曰“五行错王，相据以生”。 错王者，即子南午北，互为纲纪之意； 相据者，即龙西虎东，建纬卯酉之意； 以常道言之，金在矿中，无由自出，木带阴气，岂能滋生？ 必先用南方木中之火，去煅北方水中之金，销矿存金，金华始得发露，旋用西方水中之金，来制东方火中之木，伐去阴气，木液方得滋荣； 故曰“火性销金，金伐木荣”。 此即“五行错王，相据以生”之旨也。 东三南二合成一五，北一西四合成一五，中央戊己真土自成一五，是谓“三五混，南北併，东西攒簇于中土之内”。 是之谓“一三五合而为一，乃造化至精至妙之理”。 把握乾坤，包括河洛，其间作用必须真师口口相授，岂能笔之于书哉？ 故曰“三五为一，天地至精，可以口诀，难以书传”。 此段言颠倒二物，则五行复归于一。 末篇法象章云：“本之但二物兮，末乃为三五，三五併为一兮，都集归一所”。 印证甚明。 子当右转，午乃东旋，卯酉界隔，主客二名。 此节言金木间隔，当加沐浴之功也。 以常道五行言之，木生在亥，震木生于坎水，是谓“龙从水里出”； 金生在巳，兑金产自离火，是为“虎向火中生”； 丹道逆用则不然，从子右转到未，自北而西，以讫于南，中藏酉金，则金华产于坎中，而为上弦之气，所谓“虎向水中生”也； 从午逆旋到丑，自南而东，以至于北，中藏卯木，则流珠取之离内，而为下弦之气，所谓“龙从火里出”也； 但当子南午北，水火交入之时，一金一木界限其中，木性在东为主，金情在西为客，未免性情间隔，宾主乖违，此时须用沐浴之法，万缘尽空，一丝不挂，存真意于规中，和合金情木性。 至于金返在东，转而为主，木返在西，转而为客，主客互易其名，两弦之气始合而为一矣。 只此性情二物，自其相倡和而言，则为夫妇； 自其相生而言，则为母子； 自其相制而言，则为父子； 自其互换而言，则又为主客； 颠倒莫测，正见天地至精之理。 龙呼于虎，虎吸龙精，两相饮食，俱使合併，遂相衔咽（xian yan），咀嚼相吞。 此节言两物之相併也。 五行相据，主客既已互换，则木龙反据酉位，而呼黑虎之气； 金虎反据卯位，而吸赤龙之精； 故曰“龙呼于虎，虎吸龙精”。 于是两者性情系恋，恣意交欢，相与饮食，合併为一，且其合併之时，遂相衔相咽，吞入口中，而结一黍之丹矣。
chunks.translated_text:
Once the true seed resides in the Central Palace,
The outer defenses must be strictly guarded—
Firmly sealing the eight gates, encircling and closing them tight,
Not allowing the slightest slack.
This is like a child in infancy:
Nurture depends on the compassionate mother,
While discipline relies entirely on the stern father.
Thus it is said: *“The stern father issues commands, instructing descendants.”*

The compassionate mother is likened to the civil fire,
Warming and nourishing within the chamber of spirit;
The stern father is likened to the martial fire,
Fortifying the gates and barriers.
The filial child is the true seed—
The golden flower and flowing pearl,
The two substances conjoined.

From the pressing of timely Yin to this point,
All pertains to the work of the golden elixir,
Accomplished in a single moment.
The five phases intermingle in sovereign reversal,
Mutually sustaining to generate life—
Fire’s nature melts metal, metal’s edge fosters wood’s flourishing.
Three and five merge as one,
The essence of heaven and earth.
This may be conveyed through oral transmission,
But cannot be set down in writing.

This passage speaks of the marvel of the five phases in inversion during elixir-making.
In the common Dao, the five phases follow sequential generation—
Metal engenders water, wood engenders fire—
Flowing unchecked, vital qi inevitably scatters,
Bringing one ever closer to death,
Turning life’s mechanism into one of destruction.
This is what is meant by *“the living are the root of death.”*

In the Dao of the elixir, the five phases are entirely reversed:
The flowing pearl, originally the wood dragon,
Is drawn from the fire of Li;
The golden flower, originally the metal tiger,
Is drawn from the water of Kan.
Water and fire interpenetrate, metal and wood invert—
Only then can one return to the root and restore life,
Preserving it for kalpas without end,
Turning the mechanism of destruction into one of generation.
This is what is meant by *“the dead are the root of life.”*
Thus it is said: *“The five phases intermingle in sovereign reversal, mutually sustaining to generate life.”*

*Sovereign reversal* means the north-south axis of Zi and Wu,
Interchanging as the fundamental framework;
*Mutual sustaining* means the east-west alignment of dragon and tiger,
Establishing the weft of Mao and You.
By the logic of the common Dao,
Metal lies dormant in ore, unable to emerge on its own;
Wood, laden with yin qi, how could it flourish?
First, one must employ the fire within southern wood
To smelt the metal within northern water,
Refining the ore to reveal the golden flower.
Then, one must use the metal within western water
To restrain the wood within eastern fire,
Cutting away yin qi so that wood’s essence may flourish.
Thus it is said: *“Fire’s nature melts metal, metal’s edge fosters wood’s flourishing.”*
This is the essence of *“the five phases intermingle in sovereign reversal, mutually sustaining to generate life.”*

East’s three and south’s two combine to form one five,
North’s one and west’s four combine to form one five,
The true earth of the central palace naturally forms one five—
This is called *“three fives merge, south and north unite, east and west gather within the central earth.”*
This is what is meant by *“one, three, and five unite as one—
The most refined and wondrous principle of creation.”*
Grasping heaven and earth, encompassing the River and Luo,
Its workings must be transmitted orally by a true teacher—
How could they be committed to writing?
Thus it is said: *“Three and five merge as one, the essence of heaven and earth.
This may be conveyed through oral transmission,
But cannot be set down in writing.”*

This passage speaks of inverting the two substances,
So that the five phases return to oneness.
The *Model and Image* chapter of the final section states:
*“Originally but two things—
In the end, three and five.
Three and five merge as one—
All gather in a single place.”*
The verification is clear.

Zi turns to the right, Wu rotates to the east,
Mao and You form the boundary,
Giving rise to the names of host and guest.
This passage speaks of the separation between metal and wood,
And the need to apply the work of bathing.
By the logic of the common Dao’s five phases,
Wood is born in Hai, the thunderous wood arises from Kan water—
This is called *“the dragon emerges from water.”*
Metal is born in Si, the joyous metal is produced from Li fire—
This is called *“the tiger is born from fire.”*

In the inverted Dao of the elixir, it is otherwise:
From Zi, turning right to Wei,
From north to west, and thence to south,
With You metal concealed within,
The golden flower is produced in Kan,
Becoming the qi of the upper arc—
This is called *“the tiger is born from water.”*
From Wu, rotating left to Chou,
From south to east, and thence to north,
With Mao wood concealed within,
The flowing pearl is drawn from Li,
Becoming the qi of the lower arc—
This is called *“the dragon emerges from fire.”*

Yet when Zi is south and Wu is north,
At the moment water and fire intermingle,
One metal and one wood stand as boundaries between them.
Wood’s nature, in the east, serves as host;
Metal’s disposition, in the west, serves as guest.
Inevitably, nature and disposition become estranged,
Host and guest fall into discord.
At this time, one must apply the method of bathing—
Emptying all conditions, leaving not a single thread,
Preserving true intention within the compass,
Harmonizing metal’s disposition with wood’s nature.

When metal returns to the east, becoming host,
And wood returns to the west, becoming guest,
Host and guest exchange their names,
And the qi of the two arcs finally unite as one.

These two—nature and disposition—
In their mutual resonance, are husband and wife;
In their mutual generation, are mother and child;
In their mutual restraint, are father and son;
In their mutual exchange, are host and guest.
Ever shifting, unfathomable—
This is the essence of heaven and earth’s most refined principle.

The dragon calls to the tiger,
The tiger inhales the dragon’s essence.
The two feast upon each other,
Forcing their union,
Then interlock and swallow,
Chewing and devouring one another.
This passage speaks of the merging of the two substances.

Once the five phases are mutually sustained
And host and guest have exchanged places,
The wood dragon, now occupying the position of You,
Calls forth the qi of the black tiger;
The metal tiger, now occupying the position of Mao,
Inhales the essence of the red dragon.
Thus it is said: *“The dragon calls to the tiger, the tiger inhales the dragon’s essence.”*
Thereupon, their natures and dispositions become entangled,
Indulging in unrestrained union,
Feasting upon each other,
Merging as one.
At the moment of their union,
They interlock and swallow,
Taking into the mouth and forming the elixir the size of a millet grain.

When Mars guards the west and Venus traverses the heavens, the killing qi descends—how could anything not collapse? The wildcat watches the mouse, and birds fear the goshawk; each follows its nature—how dare they make a sound?

This section describes the mutual restraint of the two substances. As the five phases clash in dominance, fire’s nature can melt metal, thus fire enters the western metal domain, forming the image of Mars guarding the west. Metal’s nature can fell wood, thus metal seizes the eastern wood position, forming the image of Venus traversing the heavens. Fire overcomes metal, and metal in turn overcomes wood, completing a rightward cycle where nothing escapes conquest—yet this is achieved through counter-restriction, employing only the mechanism of destruction. Hence it is said: *“When the killing qi descends, how could anything not collapse?”* When wood encounters metal and metal encounters fire, their natures and dispositions are naturally subdued, like the wildcat seizing the mouse or birds fearing the goshawk—at first sight, they are captured, and both fall silent without a sound. This is not forced silence but their inherent nature. Once each has attained its restraining nature, how dare they make a sound?

This passage speaks of the mutual binding and restraint of the two substances, emerging from the preceding discussion of the five phases’ conflicting dominion, and specifically expounds the meaning of "submission." For only when they unite without hindering their mutual restraint does the vital mechanism reside within the destructive mechanism. And only through restraint can they achieve union, thus reversing the destructive mechanism into the vital mechanism. The alternation of submission and consumption fulfills the great meaning of "submission and consumption" in the *Returning Elixir* chapter—this is abundantly clear, far removed from the so-called "ingestion techniques" of heterodox schools.

Yet this life-treasure, when lodged in spirit, becomes restless and scattered in thought; when lodged in essence, it is preserved but difficult to sustain. Hence it is said to ‘constantly depart from man’—it must be subdued by the golden flower.”* (From *Chapter Twenty-Five: Discerning Authenticity and Falsehood*)
